methods.name: _format
methods.rawdescription:
When converting Date object to string, javascript built-in functions may return wrong
results because it applies its internal DST rules. The DST rules around the world change
very frequently, and the current valid rule is not always valid in previous years though.
We work around this problem building a new Date object which has its internal UTC
representation with the local date and time.
   timeZone set to 'utc' to work fine.
methods.description: When converting Date object to string, javascript built-in functions may return wrong results because it applies its internal DST rules. The DST rules around the world change very frequently, and the current valid rule is not always valid in previous years though. We work around this problem building a new Date object which has its internal UTC representation with the local date and time. timeZone set to 'utc' to work fine.

jsdoctags.comment: Intl.DateTimeFormat object, containg the desired string format. It must have timeZone set to 'utc' to work fine.
Date from which we want to get the string representation according to dtf
A Date object with its UTC representation based on the passed in date info

To be called right before a potential vertical scrollbar would be removed:

methods.description:
To be called right before a potential vertical scrollbar would be removed:

  • if there was a scrollbar, adds some compensation padding to the body to keep the same layout as when the scrollbar is there
  • if there was none, there is nothing to do

otherwise a function removing the padding)

jsdoctags.comment: a callback used to revert the compensation (noop if there was none, otherwise a function removing the padding)

adding 1 month to Jan 31, 2017, the resulting date will be Feb 28, 2017.

methods.name: deserialize
methods.rawdescription:
Attempts to deserialize a value to a valid date object. This is different from parsing in that
deserialize should only accept non-ambiguous, locale-independent formats (e.g. a ISO 8601
string). The default implementation does not allow any deserialization, it simply checks that
the given value is already a valid date object or null. The `<usa-datePicker>` will call this
method on all of its `@Input()` properties that accept dates. It is therefore possible to
support passing values from your backend directly to these properties by overriding this method
to also deserialize the format used by your backend.
    deserialized into a null date (e.g. the empty string), or an invalid date.
methods.description: Attempts to deserialize a value to a valid date object. This is different from parsing in that deserialize should only accept non-ambiguous, locale-independent formats (e.g. a ISO 8601 string). The default implementation does not allow any deserialization, it simply checks that the given value is already a valid date object or null. The <usa-datePicker> will call this method on all of its @Input() properties that accept dates. It is therefore possible to support passing values from your backend directly to these properties by overriding this method to also deserialize the format used by your backend. deserialized into a null date (e.g. the empty string), or an invalid date.

components.name: DatepickerFooterComponent
components.templateData:
General Accessibility

The calendar grid provides hotkeys for changing the year and month as well as support for normal grid navigation keys.

When the month or year of the calendar grid changes as users navigate the calendar or activate the buttons for next or previous month or year, a live region enables screen readers to announce the new month and year.

The cells of the calendar body are navigable by keys while the over all calender buttons can be navigated using tab keys, which allows users to quickly navigate to their desired date on the calendar

After user selects a date, the calender automatically closes and focus moves to the text input, allowing screen readers to confirm the user's date selection

Theming

components.name: FooterComponent
components.templateData:
General Accessibility

The modal is dynamically opened outside the normal tab flow of the page and traps focus within the modal when opened.

The other elements within the page body have aria-hidden set to true when a modal is opened

Users may pass in aria-labelledby or aria-describedby attribute values through model config when opening the modal

The modal will return focus to opener element if the opener was in focus for all browsers. However, that behaviour is inconsistent across browsers if the modal was opened through a click and the opener button was not in focus on click

Through keyboard, pressing the Esc button will also close the modal (This behavior can be toggled off if needed)

Theming

$theme-modal-border-radius $theme-modal-default-max-width $theme-modal-lg-max-width $theme-modal-lg-content-max-width

components.name: RadioFooterComponent

propertiesClass.name: dataRows

components.templateData:
The radio group component allows a name value to be passed in - This name value is applied to all radio buttons within the group for Accessibility. It allows browsers and screen readers to understand which set of radio buttons belongs in which group

Each radio button will have it's aria-checked set to true when checked and false when it becomes unchecked

Only one radio button within a radio group can be focused in through tab key press. Once focused, users may select options within the radio group using the arrow keys

Screen readers should announce total number of radio buttons within the group as well as the position of the currently focused radio button as user moves focus throughout the different buttons

Keyboard Support

Key Function
Tab
  • Moves keyboard focus to the checked radio button in a radiogroup.
  • If no radio button is checked, focus moves to the first radio button in the group.
Space
  • If the radio button with focus is unchecked, it's state will be changed to checked.
Down arrow
  • Moves focus to next radio button in the group.
  • If focus is on the last radio button in the group, move focus to the first radio button.
Up arrow
  • Moves focus to previous radio button in the group.
  • If focus is on the first radio button in the group, move focus to the last radio button.

Theming

Variable {{theme.variable}} Description {{theme.description}}

components.name: TableFooterComponent

propertiesClass.name: dataRows

components.templateData:
General Accessibility

Tables can have up to two rows of header with scope="col" or scope="row" Column row headers can be defined with usaHeaderRowDef attribute. Row headers can be attached as rowHeader property to each TableDataSource

Users are allowed to define a caption inside the table tag to indicate things like title, attribution, or a last-updated date

An aria-live region is created for each table to allow screen readers to announce whenever sorting data is modified

Aria label attributes are automatically added to column headers and sortable buttons when sorting is enabled

Theming

Variable {{theme.variable}} Description {{theme.description}}

methodsClass.name: _isComparisonIdentical
methodsClass.rawdescription:
Gets whether a value is the same as the start and end of the comparison range.
For context, the functions that we use to determine whether something is the start/end of
a range don't allow for the start and end to be on the same day, because we'd have to use
much more specific CSS selectors to style them correctly in all scenarios. This is fine for
the regular range, because when it happens, the selected styles take over and still show where
the range would've been, however we don't have these selected styles for a comparison range.
This function is used to apply a class that serves the same purpose as the one for selected
dates, but it only applies in the context of a comparison range.

components.description: Component used as the content for the datePicker display. We use this instead of using UsaCalendar directly as the content so we can control the initial focus. This also gives us a place to put additional features of the display that are not part of the calendar itself in the future. (e.g. confirmation buttons).
components.rawdescription:
Component used as the content for the datePicker display. We use this instead of using
UsaCalendar directly as the content so we can control the initial focus. This also gives us a
place to put additional features of the display that are not part of the calendar itself in the
future. (e.g. confirmation buttons).
components.templateData:
<usa-calendar
  [id]="datePicker.id"
  [ngClass]="datePicker.panelClass"
  [startAt]="datePicker.startAt"
  [minDate]="datePicker._getMinDate()"
  [maxDate]="datePicker._getMaxDate()"
  [dateFilter]="datePicker._getDateFilter()"
  [headerComponent]="datePicker.calendarHeaderComponent"
  [selected]="_getSelected()"
  [dateClass]="datePicker.dateClass"
  [comparisonStart]="comparisonStart"
  [comparisonEnd]="comparisonEnd"
  (_userSelection)="_handleUserSelection($event)"></usa-calendar>

<!-- Invisible close button for screen reader users. -->
<button
  type="button"
  class="usa-sr-only"
  [class.cdk-visually-hidden]="!_closeButtonFocused"
  (focus)="_closeButtonFocused = true"
  (blur)="_closeButtonFocused = false"
  (click)="datePicker.close()">{{ _closeButtonText }}</button>

components.name: UsaSort
components.template:
<svg
  [ngSwitch]="ariaSort"
  class="usa-icon" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 24 24">
  <g *ngSwitchCase="'descending'" class="descending">
    <path d="M17 17L15.59 15.59L12.9999 18.17V2H10.9999V18.17L8.41 15.58L7 17L11.9999 22L17 17Z"></path>
  </g>
  <g *ngSwitchCase="'ascending'" class="ascending">
    <path transform="rotate(180, 12, 12)" d="M17 17L15.59 15.59L12.9999 18.17V2H10.9999V18.17L8.41 15.58L7 17L11.9999 22L17 17Z"></path>
  </g>
  <g *ngSwitchCase="'none'" class="unsorted" fill="transparent">
    <polygon points="15.17 15 13 17.17 13 6.83 15.17 9 16.58 7.59 12 3 7.41 7.59 8.83 9 11 6.83 11 17.17 8.83 15 7.42 16.41 12 21 16.59 16.41 15.17 15"></polygon>
  </g>
</svg>

components.templateData:
<label class="usa-label" [for]="id">{{label}}</label>
<select class="usa-select" [attr.name]="id" [attr.id]="id" (change)="onOptionSelected($event)" [disabled]="disabled">
  <option *ngFor="let option of options" [value]="option.value" [disabled]="option.disabled">{{option.label}}</option>
</select>

components.name: USWDSFormlyInputComponent
components.template:
<input
  [ngClass]="{
    'usa-input--disabled': to.disabled,
    'usa-input--error': showError,
    'usa-input--success': formControl.dirty  && !formControl.invalid
  }"
  class="usa-input"
  [placeholder]="to.placeholder"
  [name]="to.name ? to.name : 'input'"
  [formlyAttributes]="field"
  [type]="to.inputType ? to.inputType : 'text'"
  [formControl]="formControl"
/>

components.name: USWDSFormlyRadioComponent
components.template:
<usa-radio-group [tile]="to.tile" [formControl]="formControl" [name]="to.name ? to.name : 'radio-group'"  [ariaLabelledBy]="to.ariaLabelledBy">
   <ng-container *ngFor="let option of to.options;let i = index">
    <usa-radio [id]="id + '_' + i" [disabled]="option.disabled" [value]="option.value" [checked]="option.checked">{{option.label}}</usa-radio>
   </ng-container>
</usa-radio-group>

variables.name: usaRunTransition
variables.defaultValue:
<T>(zone: NgZone, element: HTMLElement, startFn: UsaTransitionStartFn<T>, options: UsaTransitionOptions<T>):
        Observable<undefined> => {

          // Getting initial context from options
          let context = options.context || <T>{};

          // Checking if there are already running transitions on the given element.
          const running = runningTransitions.get(element);
          if (running) {
            switch (options.runningTransition) {
              // If there is one running and we want for it to 'continue' to run, we have to cancel the new one.
              // We're not emitting any values, but simply completing the observable (EMPTY).
              case 'continue':
                return EMPTY;
              // If there is one running and we want for it to 'stop', we have to complete the running one.
              // We're simply completing the running one and not emitting any values and merging newly provided context
              // with the one coming from currently running transition.
              case 'stop':
                zone.run(() => running.transition$.complete());
                context = Object.assign(running.context, context);
                runningTransitions.delete(element);
            }
          }

          // Running the start function
          const endFn = startFn(element, options.animation, context) || noopFn;

          // If 'prefer-reduced-motion' is enabled, the 'transition' will be set to 'none'.
          // If animations are disabled, we have to emit a value and complete the observable
          // In this case we have to call the end function, but can finish immediately by emitting a value,
          // completing the observable and executing end functions synchronously.
          if (!options.animation || window.getComputedStyle(element).transitionProperty === 'none') {
            zone.run(() => endFn());
            return of(undefined).pipe(runInZone(zone));
          }

          // Starting a new transition
          const transition$ = new Subject<any>();
          const finishTransition$ = new Subject<any>();
          const stop$ = transition$.pipe(endWith(true));
          runningTransitions.set(element, {
            transition$,
            complete: () => {
              finishTransition$.next();
              finishTransition$.complete();
            },
            context
          });

          const transitionDurationMs = getTransitionDurationMs(element);

          // 1. We have to both listen for the 'transitionend' event and have a 'just-in-case' timer,
          // because 'transitionend' event might not be fired in some browsers, if the transitioning
          // element becomes invisible (ex. when scrolling, making browser tab inactive, etc.). The timer
          // guarantees, that we'll release the DOM element and complete 'usaRunTransition'.
          // 2. We need to filter transition end events, because they might bubble from shorter transitions
          // on inner DOM elements. We're only interested in the transition on the 'element' itself.
          zone.runOutsideAngular(() => {
            const transitionEnd$ =
                fromEvent(element, 'transitionend').pipe(takeUntil(stop$), filter(({target}) => target === element));
            const timer$ = timer(transitionDurationMs + transitionTimerDelayMs).pipe(takeUntil(stop$));

            race(timer$, transitionEnd$, finishTransition$).pipe(takeUntil(stop$)).subscribe(() => {
              runningTransitions.delete(element);
              zone.run(() => {
                endFn();
                transition$.next();
                transition$.complete();
              });
            });
          });

          return transition$.asObservable();
        }

functions.name: coerceBooleanProperty
functions.description: Coerces a data-bound value (typically a string) to a boolean.

functions.name: coerceStringArray
functions.description:
Coerces a value to an array of trimmed non-empty strings. Any input that is not an array, null or undefined will be turned into a string via toString() and subsequently split with the given separator. null and undefined will result in an empty array. This results in the following outcomes:

  • null -> []
  • [null] -> ["null"]
  • ["a", "b ", " "] -> ["a", "b"]
  • [1, [2, 3]] -> ["1", "2,3"]
  • [{ a: 0 }] -> ["[object Object]"]
  • { a: 0 } -> ["[object", "Object]"]

Useful for defining CSS classes or table columns.

jsdoctags.comment: the value to coerce into an array of strings

functions.name: findLastIndex

jsdoctags.comment: calls predicate once for each element of the array, in descending order, until it finds one where predicate returns true. If such an element is found, findLastIndex immediately returns that element's index. Otherwise, findLast returns -1.

projects/uswds-components/src/lib/util/t.name: usaRunTransition
projects/uswds-components/src/lib/util/t.defaultValue:
<T>(zone: NgZone, element: HTMLElement, startFn: UsaTransitionStartFn<T>, options: UsaTransitionOptions<T>):
        Observable<undefined> => {

          // Getting initial context from options
          let context = options.context || <T>{};

          // Checking if there are already running transitions on the given element.
          const running = runningTransitions.get(element);
          if (running) {
            switch (options.runningTransition) {
              // If there is one running and we want for it to 'continue' to run, we have to cancel the new one.
              // We're not emitting any values, but simply completing the observable (EMPTY).
              case 'continue':
                return EMPTY;
              // If there is one running and we want for it to 'stop', we have to complete the running one.
              // We're simply completing the running one and not emitting any values and merging newly provided context
              // with the one coming from currently running transition.
              case 'stop':
                zone.run(() => running.transition$.complete());
                context = Object.assign(running.context, context);
                runningTransitions.delete(element);
            }
          }

          // Running the start function
          const endFn = startFn(element, options.animation, context) || noopFn;

          // If 'prefer-reduced-motion' is enabled, the 'transition' will be set to 'none'.
          // If animations are disabled, we have to emit a value and complete the observable
          // In this case we have to call the end function, but can finish immediately by emitting a value,
          // completing the observable and executing end functions synchronously.
          if (!options.animation || window.getComputedStyle(element).transitionProperty === 'none') {
            zone.run(() => endFn());
            return of(undefined).pipe(runInZone(zone));
          }

          // Starting a new transition
          const transition$ = new Subject<any>();
          const finishTransition$ = new Subject<any>();
          const stop$ = transition$.pipe(endWith(true));
          runningTransitions.set(element, {
            transition$,
            complete: () => {
              finishTransition$.next();
              finishTransition$.complete();
            },
            context
          });

          const transitionDurationMs = getTransitionDurationMs(element);

          // 1. We have to both listen for the 'transitionend' event and have a 'just-in-case' timer,
          // because 'transitionend' event might not be fired in some browsers, if the transitioning
          // element becomes invisible (ex. when scrolling, making browser tab inactive, etc.). The timer
          // guarantees, that we'll release the DOM element and complete 'usaRunTransition'.
          // 2. We need to filter transition end events, because they might bubble from shorter transitions
          // on inner DOM elements. We're only interested in the transition on the 'element' itself.
          zone.runOutsideAngular(() => {
            const transitionEnd$ =
                fromEvent(element, 'transitionend').pipe(takeUntil(stop$), filter(({target}) => target === element));
            const timer$ = timer(transitionDurationMs + transitionTimerDelayMs).pipe(takeUntil(stop$));

            race(timer$, transitionEnd$, finishTransition$).pipe(takeUntil(stop$)).subscribe(() => {
              runningTransitions.delete(element);
              zone.run(() => {
                endFn();
                transition$.next();
                transition$.complete();
              });
            });
          });

          return transition$.asObservable();
        }

projects/uswds-components/src/lib/util/u.name: coerceStringArray
projects/uswds-components/src/lib/util/u.description:
Coerces a value to an array of trimmed non-empty strings. Any input that is not an array, null or undefined will be turned into a string via toString() and subsequently split with the given separator. null and undefined will result in an empty array. This results in the following outcomes:

  • null -> []
  • [null] -> ["null"]
  • ["a", "b ", " "] -> ["a", "b"]
  • [1, [2, 3]] -> ["1", "2,3"]
  • [{ a: 0 }] -> ["[object Object]"]
  • { a: 0 } -> ["[object", "Object]"]

Useful for defining CSS classes or table columns.

jsdoctags.comment: the value to coerce into an array of strings
